answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
Verify what your housing and buildings codes require in terms of reuse of the property for non-government use.  If they are in poor condition, may not be cost effective to upgrade them.  Also check to see what your State and local laws are for tenants, in California you may have to pay them relocation assistance when you ask them to vacate, could be very expensive.  If you don't have your own property real estate department, contract with a property management company for the leasing, and management with all contact by tenants through the property manager.  Tenants can be a real problem to deal with especially at Council meetings or with the press.  All that said, in these tough times, if you can make some income on the property and help someone with a reasonable rent, I would.

answers.author: Mark Abeles-Allison
answers.text:
We have a former Ag Experiment Station that was returned to our county.  We let out RFPs and found a non-profit who is running it as a energy resource center.  They pay a monthly fee, with a 5 year lease.  They have a specific mission / scope that their activities must fall within.  We are 18 months into the program now, slow but making progress.

author: Karen Walz-Fuentes
text: We are looking for innovative ideas and solutions that other local government entities are using with regard to houses/buildings on their property.  For example, often local government entities will rent out homes that exist on property that is acquired by or deeded to the entity.  The ongoing repair costs and management/staff oversight for such a program can outweigh the benefits.  Demolition is an option; but in the current economy with non-profits struggling to find affordable space, and a shortage of affordable housing in many areas has anyone developed an innovative approach to this problem.  We are looking for examples.
title: Innovative ideas for managing houses/buildings on local government property
